physDesc.p: Two pages typewritten in black ink. Archival notes read "Aldington" in pencil at the top of the first page. Unsigned. Includes a postscript.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I am enclosing a draft for two pounds and ten pence, which represents Brown’s second instalment of ten dollars of the thirty dollars he owed Richard on the agreement I made with him. There is still another ten dollars due; but as I am going to the country next week, I am terribly afraid that I shall not be able to collect it until Autumn, as the only way I can get it is by telephoning him, making a date for payment, then telephoning again once or twice after the date for payment has passed, and eventually sending in a man to get the money direct. However, I have no doubt that you will get it in time.

Do drop me a line and tell me how things are going with you, and where Richard is. You people write so seldom nowadays that it makes me feel a thousand miles away from the centre of things, "the centre of things," of course, being where there are the most Imagists at the moment.

Professor William Lyon Phelps of Yale has written a very nice, though very slight, review of us for "The Poetry Review." The paper is not out yet, but I saw the review in manuscript; it will be out in a day or two, and I will send you a copy. He is quite wild over Richard’s "Eros and Psyche," and likes your poems in this Anthology better than anything of yours he has read.

It is extraordinary how the movement is progressing. Mrs. Wilkinson of the Los Angeles "Graphic" was here yesterday. She is tremendously enthusiastic, and I think she will write up some more about us in the "Graphic." One can hardly take up a paper that does not mention some of us; in fact, it is becoming a countrywide movement this side of the Atlantic, and it is astonishing to think that a little handful of perfectly unknown poets have done this thing, for as Ferris Greenslet said to me yesterday, we have put cosmic poetry "absolutely on the blink." And it just proves what perfect sincerity and earnest endeavour will do.

I wrote so recently that there is not much to say. There is another article coming out about all the new posts in a monthly here. The author, Richard Hunt, read it out loud to me the other day. It was very interesting, but I am sorry to say that especially featured me, but that is the commission he received from the editor, and of course what helps one of us, helps all.

Our Anthology is leading the sales of this Spring’s issues of the New Poetry Series, as it did last year. I do not think it is going quite so rapidly, because then we were a freak novelty; but we have sold over five hundred copies already, and we have only been out a couple of months, so that is not so bad.
Lots of love, dear Hilda, and write when you can.
body.postscript: P.S. "The Poetry Review" has just come, and I hasten to send it to you.
